articles.headline: The Land of Rising Conservation
articles.snippet: Japan, the most energy-efficient developed country, offers a lesson in using technology to reduce energy consumption.
articles.abstract: Japan, the most energy-efficient developed country, offers a lesson in using technology to reduce energy consumption.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Jan. 5 — In many countries, higher oil prices have hurt pocketbooks and led to worries about economic slowdowns. But here in Japan, Kiminobu Kimura, an architect, says he has not felt the pinch. In fact, his monthly energy bill is lower than a year ago.

articles.headline: San Franciscans Hurl Their Rage at Parking Patrol
articles.snippet: Officials are scrambling to end abuse of the officers who hand out tickets. There were 28 attacks in 2006.
articles.abstract: Officials are scrambling to end abuse of the officers who hand out tickets. There were 28 attacks in 2006.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5 — It bears the hallmarks of a classic urban scourge: back-channel sales, assaults on enforcement officials and even death.

articles.headline: Tipping Over a Defense of Enron
articles.snippet: A central defense argument — that Enron didn’t really do anything illegal — has been given new life by Malcolm Gladwell. And it isn’t remotely true.
articles.abstract: A central defense argument — that Enron didn’t really do anything illegal — has been given new life by Malcolm Gladwell. And it isn’t remotely true.
articles.lead_paragraph: Malcolm Gladwell is one smart cookie.

articles.headline: Encouraging More Reality in Economics
articles.snippet: The departing president of the American Economic Association is trying to push economic theory further away from the free market approach.
articles.abstract: The departing president of the American Economic Association is trying to push economic theory further away from the free market approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Jan. 5 — The annual meeting of the American Economic Association, which opened here on Friday, is usually a pretty esoteric affair.

articles.headline: Job Growth Is Strong, Surprising Economists
articles.snippet: Job growth was brisk in December, further evidence that the economy is not likely to slip into a recession.
articles.abstract: Job growth was brisk in December, further evidence that the economy is not likely to slip into a recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: Job growth was brisk last month as businesses added to their payrolls with surprising confidence, further evidence that the economy is not likely to slip into a recession.

articles.headline: A New Commander, in Step With the White House on Iraq
articles.snippet: Lt. Gen. David H. Petraeus is expected to back a rapid five-brigade expansion in Iraq.
articles.abstract: Lt. Gen. David H. Petraeus is expected to back a rapid five-brigade expansion in Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 — The selection of Lt. Gen. David H. Petraeus to serve as the senior American commander in Iraq signals an important turn in United States strategy.

articles.headline: Health Guidelines Suggested for Models
articles.snippet: The fashion industry has issued guidelines to designers, aimed at promoting healthier behavior among models.
articles.abstract: The fashion industry has issued guidelines to designers, aimed at promoting healthier behavior among models.
articles.lead_paragraph: The fashion industry sells modish trapeze dresses and $800 platform ankle boots. But it also sells women an ideal of beauty embodied by the models who walk the runways and appear in fashion magazines.

articles.headline: Images of Hanging Make Hussein a Martyr to Many
articles.snippet: Saddam Hussein’s public image in the Arab world has undergone a resurgence of admiration and awe.
articles.abstract: Saddam Hussein’s public image in the Arab world has undergone a resurgence of admiration and awe.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 5 — In the week since Saddam Hussein was hanged in an execution steeped in sectarian overtones, his public image in the Arab world, formerly that of a convicted dictator, has undergone a resurgence of admiration and awe.

articles.headline: Katrina Victims Find a Solution: Modular House
articles.snippet: On the Gulf Coast, where building materials are expensive and contractors are scarce, so-called modular houses could speed the slow pace of recovery.
articles.abstract: On the Gulf Coast, where building materials are expensive and contractors are scarce, so-called modular houses could speed the slow pace of recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: PASS CHRISTIAN, Miss. — Of the hundreds of houses swept away by Hurricane Katrina in this small Gulf Coast town, only a fraction have been replaced. The price of building materials has skyrocketed, and the services of even mediocre contractors can be hard to come by.

articles.headline: Companies Pay Dearly for Tech Trade Show
articles.snippet: The annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas is a big opportunity for technology companies, but the price of participation is daunting.
articles.abstract: The annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas is a big opportunity for technology companies, but the price of participation is daunting.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a small technology company called Digeo, the annual Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas is one of the biggest opportunities of the year. For the next few days, the city will be jampacked with potential customers, partners and press — but the price of participation is daunting.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Damon Darlin

articles.headline: When Buying a Diamond Starts With a Mouse
articles.snippet: Main Street jewelers have seen their profit margins shrink and many of their brethren shutter their store doors.
articles.abstract: Main Street jewelers have seen their profit margins shrink and many of their brethren shutter their store doors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seattle

articles.headline: Bomb’s Lasting Toll: Lost Laughter and Broken Lives
articles.snippet: If the cost of the war in Iraq is measured in human lives, one block in southeast Baghdad has paid more than its fair share.
articles.abstract: If the cost of the war in Iraq is measured in human lives, one block in southeast Baghdad has paid more than its fair share.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Jan. 6  If the cost of this war is measured in human lives, one block in southeast Baghdad has paid more than its share.

articles.headline: Leadership Tries to Restrain Fiefs in New Congress
articles.snippet: Top Democrats say that keeping the goals of the party from clashing with the objectives of the independent committee chairmen will be crucial.
articles.abstract: Top Democrats say that keeping the goals of the party from clashing with the objectives of the independent committee chairmen will be crucial.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 — Less than 24 hours after taking over as speaker, Representative Nancy Pelosi summoned the new chairmen of five committees with responsibility for various aspects of Iraq policy to her office to review and coordinate plans for hearings and inquiries.

articles.headline: Bridging the Worlds of Commerce and the Arts
articles.snippet: Great Performances awards grants that are intended to bring the worlds of the arts and commerce together.
articles.abstract: Great Performances awards grants that are intended to bring the worlds of the arts and commerce together.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN her 30 years as a jazz vocalist, Ellen Christi has received numerous grants from arts organizations to finance music and theater projects in the United States and Europe.

articles.headline: Attack of the Zombie Computers Is Growing Threat
articles.snippet: Thousands or even millions of PCs are being hijacked by malicious programs to commit Internet crimes.
articles.abstract: Thousands or even millions of PCs are being hijacked by malicious programs to commit Internet crimes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In their persistent quest to breach the Internet’s defenses, the bad guys are honing their weapons and increasing their firepower.

articles.headline: The Doctor Is In
articles.snippet: A doctor's kinder, gentler philosophy generates results.
articles.abstract: A doctor's kinder, gentler philosophy generates results.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMONG a cast of hospital patients recounting their injuries and treatments on a DVD playing in the president’s office of the NewYork-Presbyterian Healthcare System, Eugene Stolowski, a former New York firefighter, stands out. Mr. Stolowski recalls leaping from a burning building in the Bronx and plunging about 50 feet before he slammed into the ground. His voice trembling, he praises a team of NewYork-Presbyterian surgeons for sparing him from paralysis, even death, by reattaching his spinal column to his neck in early 2005.

articles.headline: More $200 Million Parachutes? Don’t Be Shocked
articles.snippet: As much as new rules will reveal about executive pay, it may still be understated.
articles.abstract: As much as new rules will reveal about executive pay, it may still be understated.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT has been a bit bewildering to watch two failed chief executives in the last two weeks or so waltz away from their companies toting severance packages worth more than $200 million each. But pay experts say shareholders had better get ready for more of the same.

articles.headline: Bush Plan for Iraq Requests More Troops and More Jobs
articles.snippet: President Bush’s plan could add as many as 20,000 American combat troops, supplemented with a jobs program costing as much as $1 billion, officials said.
articles.abstract: President Bush’s plan could add as many as 20,000 American combat troops, supplemented with a jobs program costing as much as $1 billion, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 — President Bush’s new Iraq strategy calls for a rapid influx of forces that could add as many as 20,000 American combat troops to Baghdad, supplemented with a jobs program costing as much as $1 billion intended to employ Iraqis in projects including painting schools and cleaning streets, according to American officials who are piecing together the last parts of the initiative.

articles.headline: Slimmer Time in the Age of the Internet
articles.snippet: Seismic changes at Time magazine reflect the brutal cost cutting realities in the mass magazine business.
articles.abstract: Seismic changes at Time magazine reflect the brutal cost cutting realities in the mass magazine business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard Stengel, the managing editor of Time, took his wife and kids out to dinner Friday night.

articles.headline: Latest Plan Sets a Series of Goals for Iraq Leaders
articles.snippet: President Bush’s new policy establishes benchmarks for Iraqis to ease sectarian tensions and bring political and economic stability.
articles.abstract: President Bush’s new policy establishes benchmarks for Iraqis to ease sectarian tensions and bring political and economic stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7 — President Bush’s new Iraq policy will establish a series of goals that the Iraqi government will be expected to meet to try to ease sectarian tensions and stabilize the country politically and economically, senior administration officials said Sunday.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Taking Control of Electric Bill, Hour by Hour
articles.snippet: A pilot project in Chicago allows residents to save money by shifting their use of power.
articles.abstract: A pilot project in Chicago allows residents to save money by shifting their use of power.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ten times last year, Judi Kinch, a geologist, got e-mail messages telling her that the next afternoon any electricity used at her Chicago apartment would be particularly expensive because hot, steamy weather was increasing demand for power.

articles.headline: From the Mind of a TV Producer, Satellite Television in a Portable Box
articles.snippet: The Sat-Go is a mobile satellite and television system that folds up like a piece of luggage.
articles.abstract: The Sat-Go is a mobile satellite and television system that folds up like a piece of luggage.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Rick Rosner is a self-described television junkie.

articles.headline: Toyota Enters the Auto Show With a Swagger
articles.snippet: Toyota is making surprisingly aggressive moves at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit.
articles.abstract: Toyota is making surprisingly aggressive moves at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, Jan. 7 — If there is one word to describe how Toyota Motor has behaved in its 50 years in the American market, it is carefully — careful not to expand too fast or to appear brash in its goals, lest it stir up political resentment as it gathered market share at the expense of Detroit.

articles.headline: For Journalists, Politics Not as Usual
articles.snippet: With more newspapers struggling, star print reporters are making the leap to online news ventures like The Politico.
articles.abstract: With more newspapers struggling, star print reporters are making the leap to online news ventures like The Politico.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROSSLYN, Va. — The newsroom of The Politico, the (mostly) online news venture starting publication in two weeks, looks like a typical one — reporters tap on computers at adjacent desks while banks of televisions hum overhead. But unlike a standard daily newspaper, The Politico will be devoted to a single topic: national politics. Another big difference: It is hiring.

articles.headline: A Personal Computer to Carry in a Pocket
articles.snippet: The newest cellphone screens are evolving to adopt more and more characteristics of a personal computer.
articles.abstract: The newest cellphone screens are evolving to adopt more and more characteristics of a personal computer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world of desktop computing is finally going mobile, and the shift can be seen in the explosive growth of wireless data for cellular carriers.

articles.headline: New Warsaw Archbishop Quits Over Communist Collaboration
articles.snippet: Stanislaw Wielgus resigned after admitting that he had worked with the Polish Communist-era secret police.
articles.abstract: Stanislaw Wielgus resigned after admitting that he had worked with the Polish Communist-era secret police.
articles.lead_paragraph: WARSAW, Jan. 7  The newly appointed archbishop of Warsaw, Stanislaw Wielgus, abruptly resigned on Sunday at a Mass meant to celebrate his new position after having admitted two days earlier that he had worked with the Polish Communist-era secret police.

articles.headline: Private Firms Lure Chief Executives With Top Pay
articles.snippet: Private equity firms are beginning to offer compensation on a previously unimaginable scale to chief executives.
articles.abstract: Private equity firms are beginning to offer compensation on a previously unimaginable scale to chief executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert L. Nardelli’s unceremonious departure from Home Depot may spell the end of the era of super-size pay packages for chief executives of public companies, but a new refuge for lavish compensation and private jets is emerging elsewhere.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Eric Dash
